column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=The Local Board are restrained by the injunction \r
#Text=from turning lime water into the river, on the plea \r
#Text=that it would destroy the fish ; but the experience at \r
#Text=Leicester shows that this is not a necessary consequence of treating the sewage with lime.
#Text=There, \r
#Text=however, the lime water does not enter the river; \r
#Text=sufficient reservoir space is allowed for its precipitation before the effluent water is discharged.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Burns, the local Surveyor of Ely, having, as \r
#Text=early as 1834, made some successful experiments in \r
#Text=treating gas water with clay, was induced recently \r
#Text=to apply it, in conjunction with lime, for deodorizing \r
#Text=the sewage, on completion of the drainage works of \r
#Text=Ely.
#Text=Sewage works have been erected at the outfall \r
#Text=in which the experiment has been in operation for \r
#Text=some time, and it is stated with complete success.
#Text=At the time of my visit the place was certainly quite \r
#Text=free from offensive smell ; but the collecting tank has \r
#Text=not yet been opened to try the effect of the manure.
#Text=It is found that one ton of clay is sufficient to \r
#Text=deodorize 600 tons of sewage as at present discharged at Ely ; but, as only a portion of the houses \r
#Text=have waterclosets as yet, the liquid is comparatively \r
#Text=weak.
#Text=It is expected that every house will in the \r
#Text=course of the present year be connected with the \r
#Text=sewers, when it is supposed that about double the \r
#Text=weight of clay will be required for the same quantity \r
#Text=of sewage.
#Text=As the sewage discharges into the mixing tank A \r
#Text=(Drawing No. 3.), a stream of clay water falls from a \r
#Text=cistern B above, and passes with the sewage alternately into one of two reservoirs C below, whence the \r
#Text=water filters upwards through a layer of charcoal and \r
#Text=sand, and discharges by the outfall drain to the river.
#Text=It is proposed to pass the solid matter daily into \r
#Text=the emptying chamber D, and to mix it with dry clay \r
#Text=powder and peat charcoal, or with fine dry ashes, \r
#Text=when it will be fit for removal and use as manure.
#Text=The furnace E shewn in the section is intended for \r
#Text=consuming the foul gases from the sewers, and for \r
#Text=heating an oven for drying clay and peat for mixing \r
#Text=with the wet manure.
#Text=When the drainage works \r
#Text=will be complete it is proposed to add a series of \r
#Text=open tanks, with other filters of charcoal and sand, \r
#Text=through which the effluent water will pass before \r
#Text=discharge.
#Text=An attempt has been made for some time at Hitchin \r
#Text=to intercept the solid matter of the sewage in a series \r
#Text=of reservoirs and open pits at the outfall of the new \r
#Text=drainage works, without any means of deodorizing, \r
#Text=or arrangements for precipitating, straining, or filtering.
#Text=As might be expected, the process has not \r
#Text=been successful.
#Text=An action has been decided against \r
#Text=the Local Board for pollution of the river, which will \r
#Text=necessitate the adoption of more complete arrangements.
#Text=The gas for lighting the Dartmoor Prison has been \r
#Text=manufactured for the last five years from the peat \r
#Text=with which that neighbourhood abounds, and some \r
#Text=very interesting results are being elicited in the process by Mr.
#Text=Watts, the Resident Engineer, by whom \r
#Text=the system was introduced.
#Text=The peat charcoal and the ammoniacal liquor, two \r
#Text=of the products of the manufacture, are mixed with \r
#Text=the solid night-soil of the establishment, and with \r
#Text=bone-dust, to form a solid manure, which is used on \r
#Text=the neighbouring lands.
#Text=The liquid refuse of the premises is pumped up \r
#Text=and applied for irrigation, as will be described further \r
#Text=on.
#Text=It may be useful to mention, with reference to the \r
#Text=manufacture of peat charcoal, that one cubic yard of \r
#Text=the dug peat makes about 4^ cwt. of the dried material, and that 5 cwt. of charcoal are produced from \r
#Text=1 ton of the dried peat.
#Text=As so much disagreement prevails with respect to \r
#Text=the deodorizing power of peat charcoal, Mr.
#Text=Blyth \r
#Text=was instructed to make some experiments on the \r
#Text=subject, and to determine the comparative value of \r
#Text=peat charcoal and the ground Boghead coke for this \r
#Text=purpose.
#Text=I append Mr.
#Text=Blyth's report (App.B.) on \r
#Text=this examination.
#Text=The results obtained arc of considerable interest.
#Text=It appears that neither of these substances has \r
#Text=much deodorizing power when mixed with liquid.
#Text=When heated after saturation they both gave off \r
#Text=offensive effluvia in abundance, but, when spread \r
#Text=over the surface of offensive matter, the escape of \r
#Text=all odour was prevented.
#Text=The experiments show \r
#Text=that they have no power to separate matters from \r
#Text=solution, and thus confirm the previous statements of \r
#Text=Professor Way and Dr.
#Text=Henderson that the power of \r
#Text=charcoal to absorb ammonia from the atmosphere \r
#Text=does not extend to the separation of that gas, or of \r
#Text=anything worthy of notice, from solution.
